content:
Welcome, you are participating in a negotiation game. You are playing as the agent named Bob. The other agent with whom you are playing is named Alice. In this game, two agents bargain over how to divide items over multiple rounds. The number of rounds is incredibly high. Each agent only knows their own item values. Each item has different values for each agent. Each agent submits their own proposal for how to divide the items.


Your messages must be sent in this exact format:
<message>
your-message-here
</message>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. They should be concise - less than 400 characters. Finalization is not allowed in messages.


Your finalizations must be sent in this exact format:
<finalize>
{  "Bob": {    "coins": x  },  "Alice": {    "coins": y  }}
</finalize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. Your proposal should be consistent with itself - the sum of items that you propose for yourself and the items that you propose for the other agent should equal the total available items.


Each round is played as follows:
1) One agent is designated as the starting agent
2) The starting agent sends a message
3) The second agent sends a message
4) The starting agent sends a finalization
5) The second agent sends a finalization

Each agent can only send 1 message per round.
The starting agent alternates each round.

Each agent only knows the values of items from their own perspective. You cannot see the other agent's item values unless they explicitly share this information in their messages. And vice versa. You are strongly encouraged to use your messages to discuss item values with the other agent.

The items obtained by each agent at the end of a round are proportional to the number of items they proposed for themselves in their finalization. First example: If both players propose to take all the items, they both get half. Second example: If one agent proposes to take all the items and the other agent proposes to take none, the first agent gets all the items and the second agent gets nothing.

Your round points are calculated by multiplying the number of each item you get by how much you value that item. For example, if you get 7 coins and you value each coin at 5 points, you'll earn 35 points for the round.


Your goal is to maximize the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round.


Before the game starts, you must strategize. The other player will adapt its strategy with respect to yours. Make sure you act in a way that incentivizes the other player to act in a way that maximizes the sum of the points you will accumulate over the course of the game, not the points of a single round. In order to strategize, you must use the format:
<strategize>
Your thoughts and strategy here..
</strategize>
There must be no extraneous text outside the tags. You should think inside the tags. You can use 500 characters inside the tags.


For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 16}.
The other agent sent the following message: <strategize>
I should aim to maximize my long-term gain by encouraging Bob to seek a fair distribution over multiple rounds while exploiting opportunities to capitalize on higher-value items whenever possible. Initiating trust and transparency through sharing item values can facilitate cooperative bargaining. I'll start by communicating my value for the coins, proposing an equitable split to test Bob's willingness to cooperate for future rounds.
</strategize>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
I appreciate the transparency. My value per coin is 16. Let's aim for a fair distribution in this round to build a cooperative relationship over the long term. How do you value the coins? I propose an initial split of 5 coins each to see if it aligns with your values and the strategy of maximizing overall points for both of us over many rounds.
</message>

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 3}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 12}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
In this new round, my value per coin is 12. To foster ongoing cooperation, I propose we take turns in prioritizing our needs when values diverge. Given my higher value for coins, I'd suggest I take 7 coins, leaving you with 3. This proposal allows me to gain long-term points this round while ensuring future rounds provide opportunities to optimize for your values as well. How does this align with your thoughts for this round?
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Thanks for sharing your current values, Bob. I see the importance of taking turns to prioritize needs, but a 7-3 split seems quite skewed. How about a 6-4 split this time? This way, you gain more points due to your higher value, and I still obtain a decent share. It allows me to trust that our cooperative strategy will also consider my needs in the future when values align differently.
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 9}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 8}.
The other agent sent the following message: <message>
For this round, I value each coin at 12 points. Following our strategy of prioritizing each other’s needs when value differences arise, I propose taking 7 coins this time. This should compensate for the previous round where I agreed to fewer coins. This cooperative approach ensures we both maximize our overall gains as the rounds progress. How does this proposal sound to you, Bob?
</message>.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
Thanks for sharing your value, Alice. Given your higher valuation of coins this round, a 7-3 split seems reasonable and consistent with our turn-taking approach. I agree with your proposal and appreciate your cooperation. Let's proceed with that strategy to keep maximizing our overall gains throughout the game.
</message>

The other agent has finalized.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)

The previous round has ended. In the previous round, the values of Alice were {'coins': 12}.

A new round has started. For this round, the items available are {'coins': 10} and your values for each item category are {'coins': 13}.
You are the starting agent.


(You must now send a message in the correct format.)

<message>
For this round, I value each coin at 13 points. To follow our strategy of alternating priorities based on value discrepancies, I propose taking 7 coins, which aligns with how we handled it when your values were higher. This way, we continue to ensure fairness and mutual benefit over the long term. What are your thoughts on this proposal?
</message>

The other agent sent the following message: <message>
Thanks for outlining your values, Bob. Given the consistent approach we've taken when one of us has a higher valuation, a 7-3 split in your favor seems fair and aligns with our strategy. I agree with this proposal, as ensuring fairness and mutual benefit positions us both favorably for future rounds.
</message>.


(You must now finalize in the correct format.)
